description: First attested in mid 13th century. From Middle English abrood (“broadly widely scattered”), from a- (“on, in”) + brood (“broad”). Equivalent to a- +‎ broad.

entries.meaning: Beyond the bounds of a country; in foreign countries. [from 1350–1470]
(dated) At large; widely; broadly; over a wide space. [from 1150–1350]
examples: A tree spreads its branches abroad.

entries.meaning: (dated) Without a certain confine; outside the house; away from one's abode. [from 1150–1350)]
examples: She spoke to Strickland in a language of her own, and whenever in her walks abroad she saw things calculated to destroy the peace of Her Majesty the Queen Empress, she returned to her master and gave him information.

entries.meaning: (dated) Before the public at large; throughout society or the world; here and there; moving without restriction. [from late 15th c.]
Not on target; astray; in error; confused; dazed. [from early 19th c.]
(sports) Played elsewhere than one's home grounds.
(rare, Scotland) Countries or lands abroad. [First attested in the mid 19th century.]
